content.description: On the west face of the southern of the two large boulders, (Not Copperhead) is an arete behind a tree.  Climb this slabby arete.

A rad little sloper problem that is (relatively) rarely climbed on the Copperhead boulder but deserves more attention.

The description in the black guide is to start with feet on the right wall, and goes at v4. This works pretty well, and makes for good movement.

To make it better, harder, and a purer line, start with one hand on the wall, and jump up left onto slopers (v6?)-- I had to do another couple of campus moves on slopers before I could put my foot on.
content.location:
This line is right of Lance's Dihedral. The finish holds, on the right side of Lance's actually form part of the rail that you finish on for this problem.

If you want to start it with the original beta in the guide, use the boulder behind the tree for feet. If you want to try the campus/jump start, avoid this boulder. Either way, it's really fun.

content.description: Start sitting on the low left hand pinch and right hand on a crimp. Shoot up with to a sloper and then move into twisted.
content.location: Secret Garden on the Copperhead Boulder

content.description: Slab with good edges.
content.location: On the east of Copperhead is a slab with three slab routes.  This is the middle one.

content.description: A slabby climb that uses an obvious right-facing jug as the first right foothold.  Good edges.
content.location: On the east side of Copperhead, the Northern of the two large boulders, is a large slab (three slab routes climb this slab) this climbs the northern route (rightmost).

content.description: Climb the obvious shothole arete
content.location: obvious arete on boulder between Copperhead boulder and the road

content.description: From the entrance trail between the two street signs, walk 30 seconds to a large boulder with a bolt ladder.  Take a left and there is a small boulder with an overhanging face almost immediately.  Start with one hand on the sloper and and one on the arete, go up, and do the beached whale over the top.  This description is longer than the problem.

I don't like bouldering very much but even I can admit this problem is really fun.  Start up the arete using the drill scars and an occasional left foot smear or right foot heel hook.  This problem isn't very tricky or sequential; it's just a matter of working your way up and daring to go higher and higher.  The topout is an airy and exciting mantle.  As soon as you get on top you'll want to go do it again!
content.protection: Crash pad.  The ground is sloping and the climb moves out and left, so you'll probably want a spotter to move the pad as you go.
content.location: Up the obvious east arete on the south boulder.  Directly to the right of Shot Hole Arete (V8).

content.description: Slabby arete that climbs well.
content.location: On the east side of the Copperhead Boulder is a large slab.  This climbs the arete on the South end.

content.description: Starts in dihedral left of copper-head. Stem and crimp your way up to the sloper, then go to the fin for an easy top-out.
A nice rail hand traverse.  It works left to right and end on Slab 3. Start on the chalked hold and traverse right (not using the other boulder), turn the corner and end on jugs to the arete.
content.location: In between the two large boulders in the gap on the eastern side. Start on the large chalked hold.

content.description: Same as Copperhead but using a LH sloper hold from Manly Arete
Arete immediately right of twisted

Starts in the obvious dihedral on the Copperhead on a flat shelf and a fingertip layback. This problem has a sit start variant at V7 and a V8 variant that moves up and left off of the right hand under-cling.
Start on leftmost slopers and end on Jonny's mantle
content.location: Start on leftmost slopers and end on Jonny's mantle

content.description: Start on poor slopers about 5ft up and mantle to a shallow one finger pocket
SDS as twisted and head straight up in between twisted and bear hug.
content.location: In between twisted and bear hug.

content.description: The slightly overhanging copper colored face on your right as you walk into the Secret Garden.  It's to the right of the Manly Arete and left of Lance's. The boulder is named for this problem.  Start with a left sidepull and a right crimp.  Do one hard move to a bad crimper then punch it to the bigger holds.  The line is very obvious. I believe there is a sit start variation that goes around V13.
Start with LH crimp on the face and better sidepull on the arete (both at shoulder height) and head straight up,
Stand start using two slopy overhead pinches. Smaller folks like me might have to use the right hand undercling meat hook at chest level for the start or a pad stack.
content.protection: 3 pads and a spotter. The top is safe with the right beta but you don't want to fall into that tree in case a foot blows.

content.description: Start with your left hand on a sidepull/undercling and right hand on a crimp. Move up to a right hand finger stack and then a big move with the left hand to a sloper. Bear hug (literally) your way to the top.
content.location: North side of the Copperhead boulder

content.description: Backdoor bearhug but finish on Funky bunch instead
content.location: Start on leftmost slopers and traverse in to funky bunch

climbs.name: Back Door Bear Hug (AKA Mr. Mom the hard way)

content.description: A challenging extension to Bear Hug. As you look at Bear Hug head-on, notice the sloper extension on the left. Start on the two left most slopers or on the blocky jug 1ft further left, with a good foot rail. Traverse right using the slopers. Connect into Bear Hug and keep it together for the top out.
content.protection: 3-4 pads. Careful for the tree. Head injuries have occurred as a result of hitting the roots.
content.location: Left of Bear Hug, the long sloper section is visible. (On the copperhead boulder).
